[[entrepreneur]], [[businessman]] |salary = |networth = |spouse = Mimi Leonard (1978–1992) |children = Juliet Clifton Rubin, Adam Winship Rubin |website = }} '''Jerry Clyde Rubin''' (July 14, 1938 – November 28, 1994) was an American social activist, anti-war leader, and [[counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]] icon during the 1960s and 1970s. During the 1980s, he became a successful businessman. ==Early life and education== Rubin was born in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], the son of a truck driver who later became a [[Teamsters]]' union official.[https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/30/obituaries/jerry-rubin-56-flashy-60-s-radical-dies-yippies-founder-and-chicago-7-defendant.html Jerry Rubin, 56, Flashy 60's Radical, Dies; 'Yippies' Founder and Chicago 7 Defendant] by Eric Pace in International New York Times, November 30, 1994. Accessed February 12, 2015. Rubin attended Cincinnati's [[Walnut Hills High School (Cincinnati, Ohio)|Walnut Hills High School]], co-editing the school newspaper, ''The Chatterbox'' and graduating in 1956. While in high school Rubin began to write for ''[[The Cincinnati Post]]'', compiling sports scores from high school games. He attended [[Oberlin College]], and [[Hebrew University]] in [[Jerusalem]], and later went on to graduate from the [[University of Cincinnati]], receiving a degree in history.{{cite web|title=Finally, Jerry Rubin Trusts People Over 30, Especially Wife Mimi Leonard and His New Wall Street Pals|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20078011,00.html|publisher=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=December 1, 1980|accessdate=November 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204174024/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20078011,00.html|archivedate=December 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Rubin attended the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1964 but dropped out to focus on [[social activism]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/30/obituaries/jerry-rubin-56-flashy-60-s-radical-dies-yippies-founder-and-chicago-7-defendant.html |work=The New York Times |first=Eric |last=Pace |title=Jerry Rubin, 56, Flashy 60's Radical, Dies; 'Yippies' Founder and Chicago 7 Defendant |date=November 30, 1994}} Rubin's parents died within ten months of each other, leaving Rubin to take care of his younger brother, Gil, who was 13 at the time. Jerry wanted to teach Gil about the world and planned to take him to [[India]]. When relatives threatened to sue to obtain custody of Gil, Jerry decided to take his brother to [[Israel]] instead, settling in [[Tel Aviv]]. There, Rubin worked in a [[kibbutz]], and studied [[sociology]] while his brother, who had learned [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], decided to stay in Israel and moved permanently into a kibbutz. Before returning to social and political activism, Rubin made a visit to [[Havana]], to learn first-hand about the Cuban revolution. ==Social activism== Rubin began to demonstrate on behalf of various left-wing causes after dropping out of Berkeley. Rubin also ran for [[Berkeley, California|mayor of Berkeley]], on a platform opposing the [[Vietnam War]], and supporting [[black power]] and the legalization of marijuana,{{cite book |last=Lee |first=Martin A. |authorlink=|author2=Bruce Shlain |title=Acid Dreams: The Complete Social, History of LSD: The CIA, the Sixties, and Beyond |publisher=Grove Press |year=1992 |location=New York |url=http://www.erowid.org/library/books_online/acid_dreams.pdf |doi=|id=|isbn=0-8021-3062-3}} receiving over 20% of the vote. Having been unsuccessful, Rubin turned all his attentions to political protest. His first protest was in Berkeley, protesting against the refusal of a local grocer to hire [[African Americans]]. Soon Rubin was leading protests of his own. Rubin organized the [[Vietnam Day Committee]], that led some of the first large numbered protests against the [[Vietnam War]]. He took part in planning the world's largest teach-in against the war, organized rallies and demonstrations that attempted to stop a train transporting troops to the Oakland Army Base, as well as trucks carrying [[napalm]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jfki.fu-berlin.de/academics/SummerSchool/Dateien2011/Papers/duncan_boesen.pdf |title=Jerry Rubin and the Youth International Party |publisher=University of Copenhagen |date=November 2011 |accessdate=March 16, 2014 |author=Kathrine Boesen}}{{rp|4}} The Vietnam Day Committee was a unique early antiwar organization in that it enjoyed large local participation and is believed to be a forerunner to the national movement against the war in Vietnam.{{cite web |url=http://www.wiu.edu/cas/history/wihr/WIHRVolIV%20Lowe.pdf |title=Radical Action and a National Antiwar Movement: The Vietnam Day Committee |publisher=Western Illinois Historical Review |work=Radical Action and a National Antiwar Movement: The Vietnam Day Committee |date=Spring 2012 |accessdate=March 16, 2014 |author=Michael Lowe}} Rubin was one of the founding members of the [[Youth International Party]] (YIP) or Yippies, along with social and political activist [[Abbie Hoffman]] and satirist [[Paul Krassner]].{{cite book |last=Torgoff |first=Martin |title=Can't Find My Way Home: America in the Great Stoned Age 1945-2000 |publisher=Simon & Schuster Paperbacks |year=2004 |location=New York |url=http://books.simonandschuster.com/Cant-Find-My-Way-Home/Martin-Torgoff/9780743230117 |isbn=0-7432-3011-6}} The Yippies were not a formal organization with a membership list or a direct relationship with constituency, but played upon the media's appetite for anything new and different. They were influenced by [[Marshall McLuhan]]'s ideas on the importance of electronic communication, and believed that if radical events were made more entertaining the media, especially television would give them greater coverage. As Rubin recollected:
... [T]he more visual and surreal the stunts we could cook up, the easier it would be to get on the news, and the more weird and whimsical and provocative the theater, the better it would play.''Can't Find My Way Home'' 2004, p. 229.
Rubin's appearance before the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]] (HUAC) hearings is a good example of the Yippies emphasis on conducting political protest as theater, and creating as much attention as possible to their dissent by turning it into a spectacle. Rubin was subpoenaed by HUAC in Washington but instead of pleading the Fifth Amendment as was common, he entered the room dressed in a rented 18th-century American Revolutionary War uniform, proudly claiming to be a descendant of Jefferson and Paine. "Nothing is more American than revolution," he told the committee.{{cite web |url=http://www.solidarity-us.org/site/node/2843 |title=Remembering Jerry Rubin |publisher=Solidarity |work=Remembering Jerry Rubin |date=March–April 1995 |accessdate=March 16, 2014 |author=Robert Fitch}} Rubin, showing a total lack of concern or worries, lightheartedly blew soap bubbles as members of Congress questioned his Communist affiliations. He subsequently appeared before the HUAC as a bare-chested guerrilla in [[Viet Cong]] pajamas, with war paint and carrying a toy M-16 rifle, and later as [[Santa Claus]].[http://www.montgomerycollege.edu/Departments/hpolscrv/yippiemanifesto.html A Yippie Manifesto by Jerry Rubin]. History & Political Science Department. Montgomery College. Accessed April 21, 2014.Ron Chepesiuk, ''Sixties Radicals, Then and Now: Candid Conversations with Those Who Shaped the Era'' (Jefferson, NC: McFarland & Company, 1995), 182. As [[Martin A. Lee]] and Bruce Shlain remark in their book ''[[Acid Dreams]]'':
It was a political ploy designed to make a mockery of the HUAC proceedings; the congressmen were caught off guard, and Rubin's stunt became page-one news throughout the country.''Acid Dreams'' 1992, p. 202.
Another media stunt that gave the Yippies free publicity, not only in United States but all over of the world, was when Rubin, Hoffman and others brought the [[New York Stock Exchange]] to halt by tossing money into the air and watched gleefully as the stockbrokers scrambled vehemently for the bills. Yet another successful act in Yippies "guerrilla theater" was when during the Presidential elections of 1968 the Youth International Party nominated their own candidate for the presidency. The nominee was [[Pigasus (politics)|Pigasus]] the Immortal, a 145-pound (66-kg) pig that they felt was a realistic alternative to [[Richard Nixon]] or his presidential opponents, Vice President [[Hubert Humphrey]] and Alabama governor [[George Wallace]]. At the official introductions at Pigasus' first press conference, Rubin, while holding the candidate in his arms, demanded he be given Secret Service protection and be brought to the White House for a foreign policy briefing. He also promised, on behalf of Pigasus, a fair election campaign and if Pigasus won the election he would be eaten. This would, maintained Rubin, reverse the usual democratic process in which the pig is elected "and proceeds to eat the people."Quoted in ''Acid Dreams'' 1992, p. 215. In his book ''DO IT!: Scenarios of the Revolution'' Rubin says "media does not ''report'' "news," it creates it. An event ''happens'' when it goes on TV and becomes a myth."{{cite book |last=Albert |first=Judith Clavir |author2=Stewart Edward Albert |title=The Sixties Papers: Documents of a Rebellious Decade |publisher=Praeger Publishers |year=1984 |location=New York |pages=442 |url=http://stewalbert.com/sixtiespage.html |isbn=0-275-91781-9}} He goes on to say:
TV time goes to those with the most guts and imagination. I never understood the radical who comes on TV in a suit and tie. Turn off the sound and he could be the mayor! The ''words'' may be radical, but the television is a non-verbal instrument! The way to understand TV is to shut off the sound. No one remembers any words they hear; the mind is a technicolor movie of images, not words. I've never seen "bad" coverage of a demonstration. It makes no difference what they ''say'' about us. The picture is the story.''The Sixties Papers'' 1984, p. 443.
In October 1967, [[David Dellinger]] of the [[National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam]] asked Rubin to help mobilize and direct a [[March on the Pentagon]].[http://www.uic.edu/orgs/cwluherstory/jofreeman/photos/Pentagon67.html Levitate the Pentagon] The protesters gathered at the [[Lincoln Memorial]] as Dellinger and [[Dr. Benjamin Spock]] gave speeches to the mass of people.[http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/web/20051021-pentagon-vietnam-protest-washington-dc-lyndon-johnson-jerry-rubin-david-dellinger-allen-ginsberg-yippie-robert-mcnamara.shtml The Day The Pentagon Was Supposed To Lift Off Into Space] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051219220648/http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/web/20051021-pentagon-vietnam-protest-washington-dc-lyndon-johnson-jerry-rubin-david-dellinger-allen-ginsberg-yippie-robert-mcnamara.shtml |date=December 19, 2005 }} From there, the group marched towards the Pentagon. As the protesters neared the Pentagon, they were met by soldiers of the [[82nd Airborne Division]]. who formed a human barricade blocking the Pentagon steps. Not to be dissuaded, [[Abbie Hoffman]], co-founder of the Yippies, vowed to levitate the Pentagon while [[Allen Ginsberg]] led Tibetan chants to assist. Eventually, things turned ugly. By the time the group's 48-hour permit expired, approximately 680 protesters had been jailed and 50 hospitalized. As one member of the march recalled: {{quote|Then someone in authority decided that the Pentagon steps had to cleared. Rifle butts came down on people's heads with dull ugly wet sounding thumps. Blood splashed on to the steps. There were shouts of "Link arms! Link arms!", mixed with screams of pain and curses. People were dragged off and arrested. The brutality was appalling and the people standing on the steps began throwing debris at the soldiers. I saw a garbage can sail over my head. I feared people might be trampled in panic as they tried to escape from the clubs and rifle butts.[http://www.uic.edu/orgs/cwluherstory/jofreeman/photos/Pentaremember3.html Remembering the Pentagon March (1967)]}} In spite of the brutality of the police the spirits of the demonstrators were not dampened. Many were exhilarated by what had transpired and some felt it was an event that would mark a turning point. "It made me see we could build a movement by knocking off American symbols," said Rubin.''Acid Dreams'' 1992, p. 205. He added: {{quote|We had symbolically destroyed Pentagon, the symbol of the war machine, by throwing blood on it, by pissing on it, dancing on it ... painting 'Che lives' on it. It was a total cultural attack on the Pentagon. The media had communicated this all over the country and lots of people identified with us, the besiegers.}} Rubin later played an instrumental role in the [[1968 Democratic National Convention protest activity|anti-war demonstration]] that accompanied the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]] in Chicago by helping to organize the Yippie "Festival of Life" in [[Lincoln Park]]. He spoke along with Hoffman at an anti-war rally at the [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]] bandshell on August 28, 1968 and instructed demonstrators to resist if a riot broke out. However, the extent of violence between Chicago police and demonstrators (which an official government report called a "[[police riot]]") was not anticipated by the Yippie leaders. Some 1,500 people including civilians and police were injured.{{rp|11}} The arrest and trial of the Yippie leaders (known later as the Chicago Conspiracy Trial) which began on September 24, 1969 eventually led to the conviction of Rubin and seven others on charges of incitement to riot,{{rp|10}} including [[Abbie Hoffman]], [[Rennie Davis]], [[John Froines]], [[David Dellinger]], [[Lee Weiner]], [[Tom Hayden]], and [[Bobby Seale]].{{cite book |last=Schultz |first=John |title=No One Was Killed: The Democratic National Convention, August 1968 |publisher=The University of Chicago Press |year=2009 |location=Chicago |pages=|url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/presssite/metadata.epl?isbn=9780226740782 |isbn=978-0-226-74078-2}} The defendants were commonly referred to as the "[[Chicago Eight]]". Seale's trial, however, was severed from the others after he demanded the right to serve as his own lawyer and was sentenced to four years in prison for contempt of court, making the Chicago Eight the Chicago Seven. The trial developed into a quiet spectacle, or "hippie-guerillas theater" as Rubin described it. Rubin, Hoffman and other defendants intentionally and successfully made a mockery of the court, widely covered by the press, with reporters from the ''[[New York Times]]'' and the ''[[Washington Post]]'' reporting on it. Rubin, who had declared the trial to be "the Academy Award of protest"''The Sixties Papers'' 1984, p. 42. at one point paraded back and forth in front of Judge [[Julius Hoffman]] (no relation to defendant Hoffman), thrusting his arm in a Nazi salute and shouting "Heil Hitler!"[http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/Chicago7/RubinJ.htm Jerry Rubin.] "The Chicago Seven" Trial 1969–1970 Homepage. Accessed April 1, 2014. Another time he and Hoffman wore judge's robes to court. Judge Hoffman ordered both men to remove the robes. They did - but underneath they wore blue Chicago police shirts. "The day Abbie and I came in wearing judges' robes was a stoned idea," Rubin said later. "It was a turning point in the trial in terms of theatrics, and it just went on from there."''Can't Find My Way Home'', p. 237. In spite of the danger of being busted, Rubin smoked marijuana before the trial. "I got stoned a lot for the trial because it was such complete theater – a front-row seat to history – and marijuana intensifies every experience."''Can't Find My Way Home'', pp. 236–237. Judge Hoffman added to the spectacle. Among other things, Hoffman ordered Black Panther leader [[Bobby Seale]] chained and gagged during part of the trial.[http://articles.latimes.com/1994-11-29/news/mn-2786_1_jerry-rubin 60s Activist Jerry Rubin Dies After Auto Injuries] by Shawn Hubler in Los Angeles Times, November 29, 1994. Accessed April 13, 2014. Rubin, along with the six other defendants, was found not guilty on the charge of conspiracy but guilty (with four other defendants) on the charge of incitement. He was also sentenced by the judge to more than three years in prison for contempt of court. All the convictions for incitement were later overturned by an appeals court, who cited judicial and prosecutorial misconduct. Most of the contempt of court citations were also overturned on appeal.{{cite book |last=Schultz |first=John |title=The Chicago Conspiracy Trial: Revised Edition |publisher=The University of Chicago Press |year=2009 |location=Chicago |url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/presssite/metadata.epl?isbn=9780226741147 |isbn=978-0-226-74114-7}} The retrial was held in 1972.{{rp|12}} The Vietnam War politicized marijuana, turning it from a sign of an immoral or corrupt person, suffering from [[amotivational syndrome]] (psychological condition associated with diminished inspiration to participate in social activities) into deliberate, calculated civil disobedience. Jerry Rubin remarked in 1970:
Smoking pot makes you a criminal and a revolutionary. As soon as you take your first puff, you are an enemy of society.{{cite book |last=Booth |first=Martin |authorlink=|author2= |title=Cannabis: A History |publisher=Bantam Books |year=2003 |location=London |url= |doi=|id=|isbn=}}
[[File:Jerry Rubin, activist at Flamingo Park during the 1972 Republican National Convention - Miami, Florida (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Rubin protesting during the 1972 Republican National Convention]] [[File:Jerry Rubin, activist at Flamingo Park during the 1972 Republican National Convention - Miami, Florida 2 (cropped2).jpg|thumb|right|1972 Republican convention]] In 1972, Rubin was at it again, this time in Miami Beach to organize protests for both the [[1972 Republican National Convention|Republican]] and [[1972 Democratic National Convention|Democratic Conventions]]. This time, the local community knew the Yippies were coming and they organized behind a Rubin of their own, [[Ellis Rubin]], a well known attorney. On June 4, 1972, the Rubins debated at the Unitarian Church in Miami, in front of 500 highly charged churchgoers on both sides of the issue, only divided by a church aisle. Jerry began the debate by thanking "Uncle Ellis" for the invitation to debate. Ellis, who was not related to Jerry feigned disgust at the association and the event was "on". After barbs in both directions, it ended abruptly when Jerry famously dropped an "F-bomb" and Ellis took leave to lead the locals out in a protest of their own.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19720605&id=X0VQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6VcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7298,982152|title=Two Rubins Debate Protesters' Role|publisher=[[The Evening Independent]]|date=June 5, 1972}} Rubin was also interviewed by journalist [[Dorothy Fuldheim]] about his book ''Do It''. In the interview, Rubin started to quiz Fuldheim, asking her if she drank. He then referred to the police as "pigs," which offended Fuldheim, who replied, "I've got a shock for you. Some of my friends are policemen". Rubin then muttered "Well, I've got a shock for you. I'm good friends with the Black Panthers." At this, Fuldheim threw his book and kicked Rubin off the set saying "Out! Stop the interview" as the cameras rolled.{{cite book |last1=O'Dell |first1=Cary |title=Women Pioneers in Television: Biographies of Fifteen Industry Leaders |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=74fnsRmeeZcC&lpg=RA1-PA111&ots=E81uzNOPjI&dq=dorothy%20fuldheim%20jerry%20rubin&pg=PA111#v=onepage&q=dorothy%20fuldheim%20jerry%20rubin&f=false |accessdate=August 1, 2009 |year=1997 |publisher=McFarland and Company |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |isbn=0-7864-0167-2 |oclc=35646616}} ==Post-activism== Rubin held a post-election party at his place in New York in January 1973, attended by [[John Lennon]] and [[Yoko Ono]], after McGovern lost to Nixon. Soon, Rubin retired from politics entirely, and became an [[entrepreneur]] and businessman. He was an early investor in [[Apple Computer]],Timothy Stanley (May 14, 2008), {{cite web|url=http://www.the-utopian.org/2008/05/000026.html |title=The Long Haired Conservatives: the Children of '68 Reconsidered |accessdate=September 26, 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820113819/http://www.the-utopian.org/2008/05/000026.html |archivedate=August 20, 2008 |df= }} and by the end of the 1970s had become a multimillionaire. Apple didn’t go public until 1980, so how could that investment make him a millionaire. In the 1980s, he embarked on a debating tour with [[Abbie Hoffman]] titled "[[Yippie]] versus [[Yuppie]]". Rubin's argument in the debates was that activism was hard work and that the abuse of drugs, sex, and private property had made the [[counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]] "a scary society in itself." He maintained that "wealth creation is the real American revolution. What we need is an infusion of capital into the depressed areas of our country." A later political cartoon portrayed Rubin as half-guerrilla and half-businessman.[http://www.ep.tc/realist/130/ The Realist] Rubin's differences with Hoffman were on principle rather than personal. When Hoffman committed suicide in 1989, Rubin attended his funeral.[http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-20/news/mn-2279_1_youth-international-party-abbie-hoffman-jerry-rubin Turbulent '60s Live Again at Funeral for Activist Radicals, Friends Bid Hoffman Farewell] In his memo's ''Growing (Up) at Thirty-Seven'' Rubin emphasizes the importance of uniting the personal and the political. He writes: {{quote|Friends ask me, "Isn't your inward growth trip an escape from social reality?" Yes, it's a far cry from leading a march on [[the Pentagon]] to sitting cross-legged, counting my breaths. But there is no contradiction. We activists in the 1960's eventually lost touch with ourselves. [[Arica School|Arica]], [[Erhard Seminars Training|est]], bioenergetics, and other growth trips are to creating a centered individual who moves politically from a deep place. Dissatisfaction is not the only source for political action; people can be political from a personally satisfied place ... We have an opportunity to transform the planet, but first we need to free ourselves from the conditioning of the past and find our natural internal harmony; to lower our defenses and establish our common humanity.{{cite book|last1=Rubin|first1=Jerry|title=Growing (Up) At Thirty Seven|date=1976|publisher=M. Evans and Company|isbn=0-87131-189-5}}{{rp|197,199}}}} ==Other appearances== Jerry Rubin appeared posthumously in the 2002 British documentary by [[Adam Curtis]], ''[[The Century of the Self]]''. He appears in episode part 3 of 4.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1139170/|title=The Century of the Self - There Is a Policeman Inside All Our Heads: He Must Be Destroyed|author= Adam Curtis|publisher=BBC|date=2002|accessdate=February 17, 2015}} This segment of the documentary discusses the [[Erhard Seminars Training]], also known as The ''[[Erhard Seminars Training|est]]'' Training, of which Rubin was a graduate. In his autobiography ''Growing (Up) at Thirty-Seven'' Rubin dedicates a chapter on his experience of taking the est Training. He explains why est appealed to him, even though he had initially resisted it: {{quote|Something theatrically revolutionary was happening at est. In the 1960's we had used political guerrilla theater to get people to see beyond their roles. Now Werner was creating a psychological theater provoking people into self-confrontation. Whenever people discover themselves, they grow and learn − and that has to be revolutionary. (My act is liking something ''only'' if I can call it "revolutionary".) {{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rKToNkxZ_vkC&pg=PA253&dq=growing+up+at+thirty+jerry+rubin+est&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bN3hVLWICMvSaIP5gZgE&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=growing%20up%20at%2|title=American Spiritualities: A Reader|author=Catherine L. Albanese|publisher=Indiana University Press|date=2001|accessdate=February 16, 2015}}}} Rubin also appeared on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''{{'}}s second episode of its first season. He was announced as "Jerry Rubin, Leader of the Yippie Movement." The sketch is a fake commercial for wallpaper featuring famous protest slogans from the 1960s and 1970s (e.g., "Make Love, Not War", "Off The Pig!", "Give Peace A Chance", "Hell, No, We Won't Go!", etc.). He ends the sketch by parodying a famous radical slogan as "Up against the wall-paper, posters!" (with the last word bleeped out in a reference to [[Up Against the Wall Motherfuckers]]).[http://www.vulture.com/2015/02/New-york-magazine-original-review-saturday-night-live.html New York Magazine’s Original 1975 Review of Saturday Night Live] by Jeff Greenfield October 27, 1975 issue of New York. Accessed February 12, 2015.[http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75bwallpaper.phtml Up Against the Wallpaper] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212211958/http://snltranscripts.jt.org/75/75bwallpaper.phtml |date=February 12, 2015 }} by Michael O'Donoghue, Saturday Night Live Transcripts. Season 1: Episode 2. Accessed February 12, 2015. ===Portrayal in popular culture=== In a motion picture about [[Abbie Hoffman]], ''[[Steal This Movie]]'', Rubin was portrayed by [[Kevin Corrigan]]. Rubin's love for and promotion of countercultural murderer [[Charles Manson]] is chronicled in the film [[Helter Skelter (2004 film)|''Helter Skelter'' (2004)]].For published references, including to Rubin's admiring book, ''We Are Everywhere'', see http://digital.lib.lehigh.edu/trial/reels/films/list/0_12_9. In the 2007 documentary ''Chicago 10: The Convention Was Drama. The Trial Was Comedy'' Rubin is featured both with film footage and with animation using [[Mark Ruffalo]] as his voice. In the television show ''[[Dark Skies]]'', Rubin is shown organizing an anti-war protest group in [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]] that has been infiltrated by aliens; he is portrayed by [[Timothy Omundson]]. ==Author== Rubin's anti-establishment beliefs were put down in writing in his book, ''DO IT!: Scenarios of the Revolution'' (1970), with an introduction by [[Black Panther Party|Black Panther]] [[Eldridge Cleaver]] and unconventional design by [[Quentin Fiore]]. In 1971, his journal, written while incarcerated in the [[Cook County Jail]], was published under the title ''We are Everywhere.'' The book includes an inside view of the trial of the [[Chicago Seven]], but otherwise focuses on the [[Weatherman (organization)|Weather Underground]], the [[Black Panthers]], [[LSD]], [[women's rights|women's liberation]] and his view of a coming revolution. In 1976, Rubin wrote another book entitled ''Growing (Up) at Thirty-Seven'', which contained a chapter about his experience at an [[Erhard Seminars Training]] (EST) session, later included in the book ''American Spiritualities: A Reader'' (2001) edited by Catherine L. Albanese.[http://www.books.google.dk/books?isbn=0253214327 ''American Spiritualities: A Reader'']{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Edited by Catherine L. Albanese. Chapter 11 ''est'' by Jerry Rubin. 2001. Indiana University Press. Accessed April 13, 2014. In ''Growing (Up) at Thirty-Seven'' Rubin claims a rational society cannot be built by people who are out of touch with themselves and can't even run their own lives rationally. Real political change will not happen unless people transform their own personal reality, and their own relationships. Much like [[Arthur Koestler]] in his collections of essays [[The Yogi and the Commissar]] Rubin argues that political work and self-development has to go hand in hand. It was important, he said, that people ''lived'' the society they hoped to create. As explained in ''Growing (Up) at Thirty-Seven'' Rubin experimented with many self-improvement techniques in order to overcome his own personal defects, everything from the ''est'' training, hypnotism, meditation and yoga to rolfing, acupuncture, the [[Arica School]], [[Gestalt therapy]] and the [[bioenergetic analysis]] of Wilhelm Reich's pupil Alexander Lowen. In a review of the book Derek VanPelt comments on Rubin's self quest: {{quote|Rubin, though a crude writer, takes it all in from a fairly skeptical viewpoint and reports in entertaining, thoughtful, and sometimes funny prose. The depth and sincerity of his search is apparent, and his call for a cooperative relationship between new consciousness and new politics is one of the more promising prospects of the seventies.{{cite web|url=http://freeingjohnsinclair.aadl.org/node/201328|title=Jerry Rubin|author=Derek VanPelt|publisher=Ann Arbor Sun|date=May 6, 1976|accessdate=March 3, 2014}}}} In 1980, Rubin authored a self-help book with his wife, Mimi Leonard, entitled ''The War Between the Sheets: What's Happening with Men in Bed and What Men and Women Are Doing About It''.{{cite web|author=Steven Gaines|title=Jerry Rubin, His Penis and Me: A Very Short Story|url=http://observer.com/2014/11/jerry-rubin-his-penis-and-me-a-very-short-story/|publisher=[[The New York Observer]]|date=November 28, 2014|accessdate=November 28, 2014}} It was not well received. ==Business== Sometime in the mid-1970s Rubin reinvented himself as a businessman. Friend and fellow Yippie [[Stew Albert]] claimed Rubin's new ambition was giving capitalists a social consciousness. In 1980 he began a new career on Wall Street as [[stockbroker]] with the [[brokerage firm]] John Muir & Co. "I know that I can be more effective today wearing a suit and tie and working on Wall Street than I can be dancing outside the walls of power," he said. In the 1980s, he became known for his promotion of [[business networking]], having created Business Networking Salons, Inc., a company that organized parties at the Studio 54 and Palladium nightclubs in Manhattan, where thousands of young professionals and entrepreneurs met and shared ideas. Near the end of his life, Rubin became interested in the science of [[life extension]] and was heavily involved in [[multi-level marketing]] of health foods and nutritional supplements.[http://www.1099.com/c/co/dw/pe/economy010.html What Jerry Rubin did in his final months. Accessed March 15, 2011.] His business activities included marketing of a nutritional drink named Wow! that contained bee pollen, ginseng and kelp. ==Death== On November 14, 1994, Rubin [[jaywalking|jaywalked]] on [[Wilshire Boulevard]], in front of his penthouse apartment in the [[Westwood, Los Angeles|Westwood]] area of Los Angeles, California. It was a Monday evening and weekday traffic was heavy, with three lanes moving in each direction. A car swerved to miss Rubin but a second car, immediately behind the first, was unable to avoid him. He was taken to the [[UCLA Medical Center]], where he died of a heart attack two weeks later. He is interred in the [[Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Culver City, California]]. State Senator (D-Santa Monica), fellow [[Chicago Seven]] member and friend [[Tom Hayden]] said after Rubin's death:
He was a great life force, full of spunk, courage and wit. I think his willingness to defy authority for constructive purposes will be missed. Up to the end, he was defying authority.[http://articles.latimes.com/1994-11-29/news/mn-2786_1_jerry-rubin 60s Activist Jerry Rubin Dies After Auto Injuries] by Shawn Hubler in Los Angeles Times, November 29, 1994. Accessed March 24, 2014.
==In popular culture== * ''DO IT!'' was also the inspiration for a track of the same name on the 1972 [[Aphrodite's Child]] album ''[[666 (Aphrodite's Child album)|666]].''[http://www.discogs.com/Aphrodites-Child-666/release/381201 Aphrodite's Child – 666] * [[Danny Masterson]] portrays Jerry Rubin in the movie ''[[The Chicago 8]]'', written and directed by Pinchas Perry. It was filmed in September and October 2009.{{IMDb title|1511476}} The film is based closely on the trial transcripts and most of the action takes place in the courtroom.{{cite news |last=Beck |first=Marilyn |author2=Stacy Jenel Smith |title=Romano, Bakula, Braugher Had 'Men' Chemistry |newspaper=Jacksonville Observer |date=October 27, 2009 |url=http://www.jaxobserver.com/2009/10/27/romano-bakula-braugher-had-men-chemistry/ |accessdate=June 24, 2010}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|last=Rubin|first=Jerry|title=DO IT!: Scenarios of the Revolution|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|date=1970|isbn=978-0671205355}} *{{cite book|last=Rubin|first=Jerry|title=We Are Everywhere|publisher=[[Harper & Row]]|date=1971|isbn=978-0060137243}} *{{cite book|last=Rubin|first=Jerry|title=Growing (Up) at Thirty-Seven|publisher=M Evans & Co|date=1976|isbn=978-0871311894}} *{{cite book|last1=Rubin|first1=Jerry|last2=Leonard|first2=Mimi|title=The War Between the Sheets: What's Happening with Men in Bed and What Men and Women Are Doing About It|publisher=Putnam|date=1980|isbn=978-0399900938}} ==See also== * [[List of peace activists]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEEDB1639F937A35751C1A962958260|title=Born to Be Wild. Scratch That. Born to Be Mild.|last=Berger|first=Joseph|date=December 4, 1994|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 19, 2009}} * {{cite news|title=April 1970: Jerry Rubin leads Honeywell protest |first=Ben |last=Welter |location=Minneapolis |work=[[Star Tribune]] |url=http://blogs2.startribune.com/blogs/oldnews/archives/126 |date=November 12, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502235301/http://blogs2.startribune.com/blogs/oldnews/archives/126 |archivedate=May 2, 2012 |df= }} * {{Find a Grave|3823}} * [http://www.panarchy.org/rubin/doit.html Jerry Rubin, Do It! - extract] (1970) {{Chicago Seven}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rubin, Jerry}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:1994 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:American anarchists]] [[Category:American anti–Vietnam War activists]] [[Category:American cannabis activists]] [[Category:American communists]] [[Category:American Marxists]] [[Category:American political writers]] [[Category:Anarcho-communists]] [[Category:Burials at Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery]] [[Category:Chicago Seven]] [[Category:Critics of work and the work ethic]] [[Category:Free speech activists]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:New Left]] [[Category:Peace and Freedom Party politicians]] [[Category:Pedestrian road incident deaths]] [[Category:People from Echo Park, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Pranksters]] [[Category:Psychedelic drug advocates]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in California]] [[Category:University of Cincinnati alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Cincinnati]] [[Category:Yippies]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]]

{{Infobox Politician | name = John de Mentieth | image = [[File:Earl of Menteith.svg|200px]] | caption = [[Coat of arms]] | birth_date = c.1275 | birth_place = | residence = | death_date = c.1329 | death_place = | party = | religion = | occupation = | majority = | spouse = | children = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Sir John Menteith of Ruskie and Knapdale''' (c. 1275 – c. 1329) was a [[Kingdom of Scotland|Scottish]] nobleman during the [[Wars of Scottish Independence]]. He is known for his capture of Sir [[William Wallace]] in 1305 and later joined with King [[Robert de Brus|Robert I of Scotland]] and received large land grants in [[Knapdale]] and [[Kintyre]] for his service. ==Life== John was the younger son of [[Walter Bailloch|Walter Bailloch Stewart]], and [[Mary I, Countess of Menteith|Mary]], [[Earl of Menteith|Countess of Menteith]], the daughter of [[Muireadhach II]] Earl of Menteith.Douglas, Peerage of Scotland, p. 472, ed. 1764 John possessed the land of [[Ruskie]] in [[Stirlingshire]]. John was a party to the [[Turnberry Bond]] with his father, Walter Stewart and the Bruces, which was signed at [[Turnberry Castle]] on 20 September 1286. With his older brother [[Alexander, Earl of Menteith|Alexander]], John was involved in the resistance against King [[Edward I of England]] and were both captured after the [[Battle of Dunbar (1296)|Battle of Dunbar]] on 27 April 1296. While Alexander was released after swearing fealty, John remained a prisoner at [[Nottingham Castle]] in England until August 1297, when Edward released John from prison, on his taking oath and giving security to serve with the king in the campaign of 1297 in Flanders. [[File:John Menteith, seal circa 1297.png|thumbnail|left|150px|Seal of John de Monteith (c.1297)]] He was appointed the Constable of Lennox and was ravaging the lands of Edward's partisans in Lennox in 1301. John was sent in 1303 to treat of peace with the English, but refrained from pressing his mission. By 1303 John submitted and had been restored to Edward's favour, for on 20 March 1304 John was appointed Warden of the castle, town, and [[Sheriff of Dumbarton|sheriffdom]] of Dumbarton. Edward was keen to secure the fortification as a major access route into Scotland by sea. John, as sheriff of Dumbarton, captured Sir [[William Wallace]] in 1305 and handed him over to the English. For this John was labeled traitorous and was given the contemporary nickname ''Fause Menteith'' ("Menteith the treacherous, false"). [[Image:Fause Menteith 1.jpg|100px|thumbnail|right|The little [[gargoyle]] head of the ''Fause Menteith'' on the 16th-century guard house at Dumbarton Castle]] [[Wyntoun]], whose ''"Metrical Chronicle"'' was written in 1418, says:
''"Schyre Jhon of Menteith in tha days''
''Tuk in Glasgow William Walays;''
''And sent hym until Ingland sune,''
''There was he quartayrd and undone."''
The English chronicler [[Piers Langtoft]] states that Menteith discovered the retreat of Wallace through the treacherous information of [[Jack Short (betrayer of William Wallace)|Jack Short]], Wallace's servant, and that he came under cover of night and seized him in bed. A passage in the [[Scalachronica]], quoted by [[John Leland (antiquary)|John Leland]], notes, ''"William Walleys was taken of the Counte of Menteith, about Glasgow, and sent to King Edward, and after was hanged, drawn, and quartered at London."'' Menteith was nominated one of the representatives of the Scots barons in the parliament of both nations which assembled at London in September 1305 and was chosen upon the Scottish council, which was appointed to assist [[John of Brittany, Earl of Richmond|John of Brittany]], the new [[Guardian of Scotland]], in the English interest. John received on 1 June 1306 from Edward the [[Earl of Lennox|Earldom of Lennox]], while on 15 June he received the Warden of the castle, town, and sheriffdom of Dumbarton office for life. John returned to Scotland in October. Edward appealed to John in December 1307 to join him in resisting the revolting [[Robert de Brus]], however John abandoned his earldom of Lennox, joining Brus's side. King Robert I of Scotland, rewarded John with large grants in Knapdale and [[Kintyre]]. In March 1308, John was among the Scottish magnates who wrote to the King [[Philip IV of France]] on behalf of the nation and in 1309, he was sent with Sir Nigel Campbell to treat with [[Richard Óg de Burgh, 2nd Earl of Ulster|Richard de Burgh, Earl of Ulster]], receiving a safe-conduct on 21 August, from King [[Edward II of England]]. John's English lands were forfeited for his treason. In 1316 he was commissioned with [[Thomas Randolph, 1st Earl of Moray|Thomas Randolph, Earl of Moray]] to treat on behalf of Robert Brus for a truce with the English. John remained closely attached to the royal court, as is shown by the numerous charters he attested and was at the Arbroath parliament in April 1320, and signed the [[Declaration of Arbroath]] sent by the barons of Scotland to [[Pope John XXII]]. John was described as 'guardian' of the earldom of Menteith, as his great-nephew [[Alan II, Earl of Menteith|Alan]], as Alan was a minor upon [[Alan, Earl of Menteith|Alan I, Earl of Menteith]]'s death. John was one of the negotiators of the thirteen years' truce between Bruce and the English, signed on 30 May 1323 and was present at a Scottish council at Berwick in June. The last recorded grants to him are in 1329, during the minority of King [[David II of Scotland]]. ==Issue== Menteith, by an unknown spouse, had issue:Balfour Paul vol vi, pp 132-133 *Sir John de Menteith the younger, married Helen daughter of [[Gartnait, Earl of Mar]] *Walter Menteith *Johanna Menteith, married (1) [[Malise, 7th Earl of Strathearn]], (2) [[John Campbell, Earl of Atholl]], (3) [[Maurice de Moravia, Earl of Strathearn]], (4) [[William de Moravia, 5th Earl of Sutherland]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{DNB|wstitle=Menteith, John de (DNB00)}} * [[James Balfour Paul|Paul, James Balfour]], ''[[The Scots Peerage]]'', Vol. VI, (Edinburgh, 1909) {{DEFAULTSORT:Menteith, John de}} [[Category:1275 births]] [[Category:1329 deaths]] [[Category:People from Stirling]] [[Category:Scottish soldiers]] [[Category:Scottish politicians]] [[Category:Scottish people of the Wars of Scottish Independence]] [[Category:Signatories to the Declaration of Arbroath]]

{{update|date=July 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Krista Branch | image = Krista-branch-ttu-cain-rally-tn1.jpg | caption = Krista Branch performing at a rally for presidential candidate Herman Cain in [[Cookeville, Tennessee]]. | background = solo_singer | birth_place = [[Mount Pleasant, Texas]], United States | birth_date = | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | occupation = Vocalist | years_active = 2010 – present | label = | website = [http://www.kristabranch.com/ Official website]}}
'''Krista Branch''' is an American singer whose 2010 song "I Am America" has been called the anthem of the [[Tea Party movement]]. Branch produced "I Am America" with her husband, who wrote the song, to protest the treatment of the Tea Party by Democrats.<ref name=nyt /> After being uploaded to [[YouTube]], the song was aired on [[Glenn Beck]]'s radio show and it quickly grew in popularity.<ref name="tulsaworld">{{cite news|title=Bixby singer Krista Branch sings Tea Party praises – and creates a YouTube hit|publisher=[[Tulsa World]]|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/scene/article.aspx?subjectID=454&articleID=20100720_371_0_hrbrFo974328|date=July 20, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2011}}</ref> It was subsequently performed on [[Fox News]] and at events across the country. A former ''[[American Idol]]'' contestant, Branch was eliminated early in the process.
Branch was born in [[Mount Pleasant, Texas|Mount Pleasant]], [[Texas]] and later lived in [[Bixby, Oklahoma]]. She married Michael Branch in 2000, and together they have three children. Early in the marriage her family faced serious financial difficulties, and later, while they were living in [[Colorado]], faced the near death of their youngest daughter.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|title=Song Adopted by Cain's Campaign Also Aims to Be a Tea Party Anthem|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/17/us/politics/krista-branchs-i-am-america-aims-to-be-tea-party-anthem.html?pagewanted=all|date=October 16, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|first=Edward|last=Wyatt}}</ref><ref name=700Club>{{cite news|title=The Branchs' Miracle Baby|publisher=[[The 700 Club]]|url=http://www.cbn.com/700club/Guests/Bios/Branches040105.aspx|accessdate=October 28, 2011}}</ref>
The Branches became supporters of [[Herman Cain presidential campaign, 2012|2012 presidential candidate]] [[Herman Cain]] after performing at several events where he was a keynote speaker, and "I Am America" was made the official theme song of the campaign. Another song released by Branch, "Remember Who We Are", was made the official campaign anthem of [[Rick Santorum]]'s [[Rick Santorum presidential campaign, 2012|presidential campaign]].
Branch's music regularly expresses religious and political themes emphasizing [[American exceptionalism]]. Her music has been well received among conservative commentators and members of the Tea Party movement for its political message.<ref name=nyt /> The use of Branch's music in the campaigns of Cain and Santorum has been seen as an indication of its appeal among outsider candidates.<ref name=Slate>{{cite news|last=Weigel|first=David|title=The Rick Santorum Theme Song, Brought to You by the Author of the Herman Cain Theme Song|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/weigel/2012/03/15/the_rick_santorum_theme_song_brought_to_you_by_the_author_of_the_herman_cain_theme_song.html|accessdate=March 19, 2012|newspaper=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref> She has released nine singles and an [[extended play|EP]], and is working on her debut album for release in 2013.{{update inline|date=July 2016}}
== Personal life == Branch was born in [[Mount Pleasant, Texas|Mount Pleasant]] in [[East Texas]], and began singing in her youth at church along with her four siblings.<ref name=Dallasnews/> She also lived in [[Oklahoma]] for part of her childhood.<ref name=nyt /> Branch moved out of Texas with her family at the age of 14, but remained proud of her Texas heritage.<ref name=Dallasnews>{{cite news|title=Texas native's song becomes Herman Cain anthem|publisher=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/perry-watch/headlines/20111103-texas-natives-song-becomes-herman-cain-anthem.ece|author=Tom Benning|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=July 11, 2011}}</ref> In order to focus on her music career, Branch and her family moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 2010.<ref name="nyt"/>
She married Michael Branch in 2000, and they have since had three children together.<ref name=tulsaworld /> Early in their marriage they had a low income, and Branch's husband took on several odd jobs, in addition to his work as a youth pastor, in order to make a living. He describes living with Branch in a "shabby place" in Tulsa, Oklahoma where they struggled to pay $480 a month in rent. Later they bought a house in Tulsa, and rented it out while they were living in Colorado; they got into financial difficulties when the tenants stopped paying the rent, and they accepted the bank's decision to foreclose the mortgage, as that cleared their debt.<ref name=nyt /> They appeared on the Christian news magazine program, [[the 700 Club]], talking about an incident in which their baby daughter was revived after drowning in their bathtub, and they attributed their child's survival to the power of prayer, having been inspired after seeing ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'' a few days earlier.<ref name=700Club />
== Career == While living in [[Bixby, Oklahoma]], Branch auditioned for the [[American Idol (season 7)|seventh season of ''American Idol'']] and was chosen by the judges to move on to the preliminary round in [[Hollywood]]. Footage of her performance was not included on the show, but she appeared in a montage at the end of the episode.<ref>{{cite news|title=Four Oklahomans get to next round on 'American Idol'|work=[[Tulsa World]]|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?articleID=20080117_1__hrimg71037|date=January 17, 2008|accessdate=October 28, 2011}}</ref> A week later she was eliminated from the competition. Branch told ''[[The New York Times]]'' her decision to enter the contest was not due to a desire to "be somebody", but because she felt she should take any opportunity with the belief that God would bless her efforts.<ref name="nyt"/>
Two years later, the video for Branch's fourth single "I Am America" was released on [[YouTube]].<ref name=tulsaworld /><ref name=HuffPo /> Her husband, Michael Branch, wrote the song partly in response to criticism of the [[Tea Party protests]] from [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]], while also drawing on his own difficulties in life.<ref name="nyt"/> In an interview for Billy Kelly of [[the Washington Times]]' Tea Party Report, Branch told how soon after her husband wrote the song he had her quickly learn the lyrics and then recorded her performing the song.<ref name="WashingtonTimes">{{cite news|title=Singer Krista Branch gives the tea party movement its anthem|work=[[The Washington Times]]|url=http://communities.washingtontimes.com/neighborhood/tea-party-report/2010/jul/22/singer-krista-branch-gives-tea-party-anthem/|date=July 22, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2011}}</ref> She originally felt the song was too confrontational for her, but decided the message was so important that she should record the song.<ref name=Dallasnews /> In the music video, footage of Tea Party rallies is interspersed with scenes of Branch singing on a sound stage and kids holding signs containing political messages and [[scripture]].<ref name=HuffPo /> "I Am America" was played on the July 7, 2010, broadcast of [[Glenn Beck]]'s radio show and a week later Fox News host [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] devoted a portion of his "Pinheads and Patriots" segment to the song, saying that "for honoring legitimate protest" Branch was a patriot.<ref name="tulsaworld"/><ref name=HuffPo>{{cite news|title=Krista Branch 'I Am America' Song Supports Tea Party|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/07/07/krista-branch-i-am-americ_n_638596.html|date=July 7, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2011 |first=Tj |last=Ortenzi}}</ref> About 21 days after being uploaded the video had nearly 475,000 views. "I Am America" soon became a popular song with the [[Tea Party movement]] and has been described as the movement's anthem.<ref name=tulsaworld /><ref name=WashingtonTimes /> ''The New York Times'' described Branch as having a "dynamic presence" on stage when singing the song.<ref name=nyt />
Glenn Beck played another Krista Branch song titled "Remember Who We Are" on his Insider Extreme radio program early in August 2010 and the song was featured in a video from Branch promoting Beck's [[Restoring Honor rally]].<ref name=Beckradio>{{cite episode|url=http://www.glennbeck.com/content/show/2010-07-27/|title=Glenn Beck Program|credits=[[Glenn Beck]]|network=[[Premiere Networks]]|station=[[WOR (AM)]]|location=[[New York City]]|airdate=2010-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Glenn Beck, Sarah Palin to Hold "Restoring Honor Rally"|publisher=[[CBS News]]|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20011688-503544.html|date=July 26, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2011}}</ref> The lyrics for "Remember Who We Are" contain a mixture of defiant metaphors with a Christian rock style of music.<ref name=ColoradoIndie /> Branch's husband said he wrote the song to "remind us of who Americans are in the wake of the most trying of times." He stated that Americans stand up and come together in the face of adversity, saying he prayed the song would bring people hope.<ref name=Today /> Calling it an "inspiring patriotic song", the video for the song was made the "Video of the Day" on Glenn Beck's site on September 3, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Video of the Day – September 3, 2010|url=http://www.glennbeck.com/content/articles/article/198/45246/|publisher=GlennBeck.com|accessdate=March 22, 2012}}</ref>
Her first EP ''I Am America'' was released on September 3, 2010 by Soundmindpro Publishing, a company established by Branch's husband.<ref>{{cite web|title=I Am America EP by Krista Branch|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/i-am-america-ep/id391552323|publisher=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sound Mind Productions – About|url=http://www.soundmindpro.com/about|publisher=Sound Mind Productions|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref> The EP included "Remember Who We Are" as well as "I Am America" and "Foreign Land", a song about departed American soldiers. Jeremiah Holdsworth of IndieVision felt the songs were strong, noting their patriotic themes and subtle religious subtext, and said the song "Foreign Land" particularly moved him.<ref name=IndieVision>{{cite news|last=Holdsworth|first=Jeremiah|title=Krista Branch – I Am America EP|url=http://www.indievisionmusic.com/2011/07/16/krista-branch-i-am-america-ep/|accessdate=April 16, 2012|newspaper=Indie Vision Music|date=July 16, 2011}}</ref> Branch released a new single on July 22, 2011, called "Lead Me On", a cover of [[Lead Me On (Amy Grant song)|the Amy Grant song]] and released a video for the song a month later.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lead Me On – Single by Krista Branch|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/lead-me-on-single/id452424023|publisher=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref><ref name=JTA>{{cite news|title=Krista Branch's pro-Israel song is Amy Grant's song about the Holocaust (and slavery)|publisher=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|url=http://blogs.jta.org/politics/article/2011/10/30/3090030/krista-branchs-pro-israel-song-is-amy-grants-song-about-the-holocaust-and-slavery|date=October 30, 2011|accessdate=July 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419034728/http://blogs.jta.org/politics/article/2011/10/30/3090030/krista-branchs-pro-israel-song-is-amy-grants-song-about-the-holocaust-and-slavery|archivedate=April 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The song was described as pro-Israel with the music video containing imagery related to the history of the Jewish people, including a prominent emphasis on the Holocaust.<ref>{{cite news|title=Krista Branch, the Tea Party's siren, releases a pro-Israel song|publisher=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|url=http://blogs.jta.org/politics/article/2011/10/28/3090016/krista-branch-the-tea-partys-siren-releases-a-pro-israel-song|date=October 28, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030204506/http://blogs.jta.org/politics/article/2011/10/28/3090016/krista-branch-the-tea-partys-siren-releases-a-pro-israel-song|archivedate=October 30, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In addition to her performances in the United States, Branch has performed for teens in Guatemala and Slovakia.<ref name=WashingtonTimes /> She performed at the 2011 [[Sunbelt Ag Expo]] in conjunction with the [[American Bible Society]], singing patriotic songs to support American soldiers and performing the [[Star Spangled Banner|national anthem]] for the Expo.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sarachik|first=Justin|title=American Bible Society, Krista Branch Help Soldiers Overcome War Pressures|url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/american-bible-society-krista-branch-help-soldiers-overcome-war-pressures-58696/|accessdate=March 22, 2012|newspaper=[[Christian Post]]|date=October 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Armed Services Ministry Goes to Sunbelt|url=http://record.americanbible.org/content/armed-services-ministry-goes-sunbelt|publisher=[[American Bible Society]]|accessdate=March 22, 2012}}</ref> Branch attended the Washington Times' 30th anniversary celebration on October 3, 2012, and performed several songs for the event.<ref>{{cite news|last=Boltz|first=Martha M.|title=30th Anniversary of The Washington Times celebrated|url=http://communities.washingtontimes.com/neighborhood/entertainment-news-and-reviews/2012/oct/4/30th-anniversary-washington-times-celebrated/|accessdate=30 October 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Times]]|date=4 October 2012}}</ref> Branch regularly performs with Oklahoma jazz saxophonist Grady Nichols.<ref name=tulsaworld /> She is working on her debut album, which was scheduled to be released in early 2013.<ref name=WashingtonTimes />
=== 2012 Republican presidential primaries === Branch's music has gained prominence as a result of its use during the [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|2012 Republican presidential primary]].<ref name=Dallasnews /> When she was performing "I Am America" at events across the country, [[Herman Cain]] was often the keynote speaker. Branch and her husband came to appreciate his political views and her husband signed on with [[Herman Cain presidential campaign, 2012|Cain's campaign]]. "I Am America" was later adopted by the candidate as his campaign's official theme.<ref name=Dallasnews /> Cain said when interviewed about the song, "The first time I heard that song, the message was so right-on I felt goose bumps just listening to it."<ref name="nyt"/> The song was later described by the [[National Journal]] as having "underscored Cain's anti-elitist appeal" with its lyrics.<ref name=Journal>{{cite news|last=Boerma|first=Lindsey|title=Santorum Gets a Big Win and His Own Song|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/2012-presidential-campaign/santorum-gets-a-big-win-and-his-own-song-20120314?mrefid=election2012|accessdate=March 19, 2012|newspaper=[[National Journal]]|date=March 14, 2012}}</ref> Campaign ads featuring "I Am America" gave the song increased exposure.<ref name=Dallasnews /> A campaign ad using "I Am America" that included Cain's chief of staff was the subject of numerous parodies also featuring the song.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jon Huntsman's daughters spoof Herman Cain's smoking ad|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2054982/Herman-Cain-smoking-advert-spoofed-Jon-Huntsmans-daughters.html|accessdate=March 19, 2012|newspaper=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=October 30, 2011}}</ref> On ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', comedian Stephen Colbert satirically claimed Cain got the line "I Am America" from Colbert's book, ''[[I Am America (And So Can You!)]]''. Several parodies of the ad were then shown on the program using the song.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stephen Colbert Offers Herman Cain Suggestions For Further Commercials, Issues Challenge |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/26/stephen-colbert-herman-cain_n_1032707.html|date=October 26, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|first=Jason|last=Linkins}}</ref>
Rick Santorum announced in March 2012 that he has adopted Branch's song "Remember Who We Are" as an official theme song for his campaign, having been without a theme song prior to the announcement.<ref name=Today>{{cite news|last=Eugenios|first=Jillian|title=Santorum finds his groove with new theme song|url=http://todayonthetrail.today.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/03/15/10699939-santorum-finds-his-groove-with-new-theme-song|accessdate=March 19, 2012|newspaper=[[MSNBC]]|date=March 14, 2012}}</ref> Santorum said he chose the song because "few songs express the beauty and strength of who we are as free Americans better than Krista's." The song is seen as representing the emotion of his campaign effort.<ref name=ColoradoIndie>{{cite news|last=Tomasic|first=John|title=Fresh off southern victories, Santorum taps Tea Party singer Branch for theme song|url=http://coloradoindependent.com/115541/fresh-off-southern-victories-santorum-taps-tea-party-singer-branch-for-theme-song|accessdate=March 19, 2012|newspaper=[[The Colorado Independent]]|date=March 14, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Journal /> [[David Weigel]] described Branch as the "muse of the insurgent conservative candidate" due to her songs being used by Cain and Santorum in their primary campaigns.<ref name=Slate />
== Politics == Branch has said her patriotism and admiration for America is the unifying principle of her music. She suggests the Tea Party is animated not by rebelliousness, but by patriotism and love of freedom.<ref name=nyt /> Her music often incorporates political themes and religious views that have led to her songs resonating with Tea Party supporters and commentators such as Glenn Beck and Bill O'Reilly.<ref name=nyt /><ref name=Dallasnews /><ref name=HuffPo /><ref name=ColoradoIndie />
The artist has performed at political rallies led by Beck, and at campaign rallies for Herman Cain. Her husband joined Cain's presidential campaign as state director for Tennessee after hearing him speak at events where Branch performed.<ref name="nyt"/> Branch said Cain was a natural choice for her and her husband because she felt their beliefs aligned with Cain's.<ref name=Dallasnews /> Since 2010, she received three payments that totaled $10,000 for live entertainment services provided at political rallies from several [[political action committees]] associated with Cain's campaign.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cain Ad Stars Paid Well, Senator Wants a Super PAC and More in Capital Eye Opener: Oct. 26|publisher=[[Open Secrets]]|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/news/2011/10/herman-cain-ad-stars-paid-well.html|date=October 26, 2011|accessdate=July 11, 2011}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:Naval Jack of the Republic of China.svg|thumb|262x262px|[[Kuomintang]] party [[Blue Sky with a White Sun]] flag which was used by Xibei San Ma]] {{chinese|t=馬家軍(閥)|s=马家军(阀)|p=Mǎ Jiā Jūn(fá)|xej=ﻣَﺎ ﮐﯿَا کٌ ﻓَﺎ|l=Ma Family Army
Ma Family Military Clique}} {{For|the training group of Chinese track athletes|Ma Junren}} The '''Ma clique''' or '''Ma family warlords'''{{Cite book |first=Jonathan Neaman |last=Lipman |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |year=1998 |isbn=962-209-468-6 |title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4_FGPtLEoYQC |page=258 (the main index entry for "Ma family warlords") }} is a collective name for a group of [[Hui people|Hui]] (Muslim Chinese) warlords in [[Northwestern China]] who ruled the [[Chinese provinces]] of [[Qinghai]], [[Gansu]] and [[Ningxia]] for 10 years from 1919 until 1928. Following the overthrow of the Qing dynasty in 1911, the region came under Chinese Muslim warlord [[Ma Qi]]'s control until the Northern Expedition by the Republic of China consolidated central control in 1928. There were three families in the Ma clique ("Ma" being a common Hui rendering of the common [[Islam|Muslim]] name "[[Muhammad (name)|Muhammad]]"), each of them respectively controlled 3 areas, [[Gansu]], [[Qinghai]], and [[Ningxia]]. The three most prominent members of the clique were [[Ma Bufang]], [[Ma Hongkui]], and [[Ma Hongbin]], collectively known as the '''Xibei San Ma''' ({{zh|西北三马}}, ''Three Mas of the Northwest''). Some contemporary accounts, such as [[Edgar Snow]]'s, described the clique as the "Four Ma" (rather than Three), adding Ma Bufang's brother Ma Buqing to the list of the top warlords.[[Edgar Snow]], ''Red Star Over China''. Chapter 4, "Moslem and Marxist". Numerous editions. Other prominent Mas included [[Ma Anliang]], [[Ma Qi]], [[Ma Lin (warlord)|Ma Lin]], [[Ma Hu-shan]], and [[Ma Zhongying]]. ==Ma Clique== The Ma Clique warlords were all Generals in the military of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]], who controlled all of [[Mainland China]] until it was overtaken by the communist [[People's Liberation Army]]. The clique was begun by Muslim generals who served in the military of the Qing dynasty, most notably in the [[Kansu Braves]] army, who fought in the [[Boxer Rebellion]] against invading foreign forces. It was continued by two generations of their descendants. After the [[Xinhai Revolution]] overthrew the Qing, the Ma Clique Generals declared their allegiance to the Republic of China. Unlike the Mongols, Hui Muslims refused to secede from the Republic, and [[Ma Qi]] quickly used his diplomatic and military powers to make the Tibetan and Mongol nobles recognize the Republic of China government as their overlord, and sent a message to President [[Yuan Shikai]] reaffirming that [[Qinghai]] was securely in the Republic. He replaced "Long, Long, Long, Live the reigning Emperor", with "Long live the Republic of China" on inscriptions.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3C2B9oXVbQC&pg=PA43&dq=ma+qi+general&hl=en&ei=3C7PTIX4A8H6lweRkonlCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=ma%20qi%20general&f=false|title=Dilemmas The Mongols at China's edge: history and the politics of national unity |author=Uradyn Erden Bulag|year=2002|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|location=|page=43|isbn=0-7425-1144-8|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Ma Anliang also agreed to join the new [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] government.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=90CN0vtxdY0C&pg=PA168&dq=ma+anliang's+brother+ma+guoliang&cd=1#v=snippet&q=twenty%20battalions%20of%20loyal%20muslim%20braves&f=false|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|author=Jonathan Neaman Lipman|year=2004|publisher=University of Washington Press|location=Seattle|page=170|isbn=0-295-97644-6|accessdate=2010-06-28}} When the [[Kuomintang]] seized power in the [[Northern Expedition]], the Ma Clique warlords became members of the [[Kuomintang]] party, and their armies were renamed as divisions of the [[National Revolutionary Army]]. The Ma Clique [[Ninghai Army]] under General Ma Qi was renamed the National Revolutionary Army 26th Division. [[Ma Zhongying]] led the [[36th Division (National Revolutionary Army)|KMT 36th Division]] to fight against the pro-Soviet governor of Xinjiang, [[Jin Shuren]] during the [[Kumul Rebellion]], and the Soviets themselves during the [[Soviet Invasion of Xinjiang]]. The 36th Division also crushed the [[First East Turkestan Republic]] at the [[Battle of Kashgar (1934)]]. In the [[Sino-Tibetan War]], Ma Clique forces led by [[Ma Bufang]] defeated the Tibetan Army. Also during the [[Kuomintang Pacification of Qinghai]] Ma Bufang waged war against Tibetan tribes in Qinghai to bring them under his control. During the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], Ma Clique forces fought against the Japanese, [[Ma Hongbin]] led his 81st corps to defeat the Japanese at the [[Battle of Wuyuan]]. Ma Bufang sent [[Ma Biao (general)|Ma Biao]] to attack the Japanese army. 40 years before, Ma Biao had fought in the Boxer Rebellion against the Eight Nation Alliance. [[Ma Bufang]] was ordered by the [[Kuomintang]] to invade [[Xinjiang]] in the 1940s to intimidate and help oust the forces of the pro Soviet Governor [[Sheng Shicai]]. The Ma Clique forces also clashed with the forces of the [[Second East Turkestan Republic]] during the [[Ili Rebellion]]. ==The Three Families of the Ma Clique== * The first family was headed by [[Ma Zhanao]]. He had 2 sons, [[Ma Anliang]], and Ma Guoliang, both of whom became Qing generals. Ma Anliang later became a general in the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]]. Ma Anliang had 5 sons, 3 were unknown. The other 2 were Ma Tingran and Ma Tingxian, who was executed in 1962 by the Peoples Court. * The second family was headed by Ma Qianling. [[Ma Hongbin]] and [[Ma Hongkui]] were cousins. Their respective fathers, [[Ma Fulu]] (马福绿) (1854–1900) and [[Ma Fuxiang]] (马福祥) (1876–1932) came from Yangzhushan (阳注山) village in Hanji Town (presently, the county seat of [[Linxia County]]), and were half-brothers. Ma Fulu and Ma Fuxiang's father [[Ma Qianling]], originally a small merchant and farmer from [[Linxia City|Hezhou]], had been an associate of [[Ma Zhan'ao]] – the ruler of [[Linxia City|Hezhou]] region during the [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|Great Muslim Rebellion]] of the 1860s – and went over to the [[Qing Dynasty|Qing]] government's side in 1872 along with Ma Zhan'ao himself; rewarded by the government and successful in his business, he had four sons with his three wives.Lipman (1998), pp. 167–172 Ma Zhanao was the father of another 2 Ma clique warlords, [[Ma Anliang]] and Ma Guoliang.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=90CN0vtxdY0C&pg=PA168&dq=ma+anliang's+brother+ma+guoliang&cd=1#v=snippet&q=ma%20zhan'ao%20son%20ma%20anliang&f=false|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|author=Jonathan Neaman Lipman|year=2004|publisher=University of Washington Press|location=Seattle|page=146|isbn=0-295-97644-6|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=90CN0vtxdY0C&pg=PA168&dq=ma+anliang's+brother+ma+guoliang&cd=1#v=snippet&q=ma%20guoliang%20brother&f=false|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|author=Jonathan Neaman Lipman|year=2004|publisher=University of Washington Press|location=Seattle|page=168|isbn=0-295-97644-6|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Ma Qianling also had several nephews who died along with Ma Fulu in the [[Boxer Rebellion]]. * [[Ma Haiyan]] started the third family. He had two sons, Ma Qi, and Ma Lin. Ma Qi had 2 sons, [[Ma Buqing]] and [[Ma Bufang]], originally from Monigou Township (漠泥沟乡) in [[Linxia County]]."临夏旅游" (Linxia Tourism), published by Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture Tourist Board, 2003. 146 pages. No ISBN. pp. 68–69. Their father, [[Ma Qi]] (1869–1931), was based in [[Xining]], controlling what is today [[Qinghai]] Province. [[Ma Zhongying]] was Ma Qi's nephew, and thus a cousin of [[Ma Buqing]] and [[Ma Bufang]]. [[Ma Hushan]] was also a member of this family. This family controlled [[Qinghai]] province. One Generation of this family had the same [[Generation name]], 步 (Bù), [[Ma Bufang]], [[Ma Buqing]], [[Ma Bukang]], Ma Buluan, and Ma Zhongying (whose original name was Ma Buying) all had the Bu character in their names and were of the same generation, all being grandsons of Ma Haiyan. File:Ma Bufang.jpg|Ma Bufang File:Ma Hongkui.jpg|Ma Hongkui File:Ma_Zhongying.jpg|Ma Zhongying File:Ma Lin.jpg|Ma Lin ==History== The Ma clique traces its origins to the officers of [[Qing dynasty]] General [[Dong Fuxiang]]. General [[Ma Anliang]] was the de facto leader of the Muslims of northwest China.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=NnjsTZ2MHcnw0gHfwa12&ct=result&id=NNAMAQAAMAAJ&dq=Thus+Ma+An-liang%2C+the+leading+figure+in+Kansu+from+1912+to+his+death+in+November+1919%2C+had+led+four+ying+to+the+relief+of+Sining+in+1895.+In+1910+we+find+him+promoted+from+the+Barkul+military+command%2C+perhaps+the+key+cavalry+posting+in&q=+moslem+clique++fu+hsiang+an-liang|title=Chinese Republican studies newsletter, Volumes 5-7|author=University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Center for Asian Studies|editors=|year=1979|publisher=|volume=|location=|isbn=|page=35|accessdate=2011-06-06}} The Three (or Five) Ma took control of the region during the [[Warlord Era]], siding first with the [[Guominjun]] and then the [[Kuomintang]]; they fought against the Red Army during the [[Long March]] and the Japanese during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]]. The Ma Clique controlled vast amounts of land in the northwest, included Xining and Hezhou.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WltwAAAAMAAJ&q=ma+qi+muslim&dq=ma+qi+muslim&hl=en&ei=S3-qTP3bBoKC8gbpgKXhBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFUQ6AEwCA|title=China's inner Asian frontier: photographs of the Wulsin expedition to northwest China in 1923 : from the archives of the Peabody Museum, Harvard University, and the National Geographic Society|author=Frederick Roelker Wulsin, Mary Ellen Alonso, Joseph Fletcher, Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, National Geographic Society (U.S.), Peabody Museum of Salem, Pacific Asia Museum|year=1979|publisher=The Museum : distributed by Harvard University Press|location=|page=43|isbn=0-674-11968-1|accessdate=2010-06-28}} The [[Qing dynasty]] had granted [[Ma Bufang]]'s family a yellow standard which had his family name "Ma" on it. Ma Bufang continued to use this standard in battle.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YJqPc4tqSGEC&pg=PT253&dq=ma+bufang+buddhist&hl=en&ei=BELkTZPIKMnogAfJj-2bBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=ma%20bufang%20commanded%2030%2C000%20muslim%20soldiers&f=false|title=Unbound: A True Story of War, Love, and Survival|author=Dean King|editor=|year=2010|publisher=Hachette Digital, Inc.|edition=illustrated|location=|page=|isbn=0-316-16708-8|pages=|accessdate=2010-06-28}} [[Ma Bufang]] recruited many [[Salar people|Salar]] officers from [[Xunhua]] County into his army like Han Yimu and General [[Han Youwen]]. During one campaign against the Communists in the Civil War, in Gansu, Qinghai, and Ningxia, Muslim soldiers numbered 31,000.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=foATAAAAIAAJ&q=31000+Mohammedan+troops+(Kansu,+Ninghsia,+Chinghai)+40000+Communist+army+(Kansu&dq=31000+Mohammedan+troops+(Kansu,+Ninghsia,+Chinghai)+40000+Communist+army+(Kansu&hl=en&ei=qm_sTavcGIObtwfE6aTCAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA|title=The China monthly review, Volumes 80-81|author=|editors=|year=1937|publisher=J.W. Powell|location=|isbn=|page=56|accessdate=2011-06-06}} During the final stages of the [[Chinese Civil War]], the Ma fought for the Kuomintang side in defiance until the communists [[Lanzhou Campaign|wiped out his cavalry]] and took Gansu in August 1949, just months before the establishment of the People's Republic of China. Upon [[Lanzhou Campaign|the arrival of communist forces]], Ma Hongbin had little possibility of winning and went to communists side. He was appointed vice-chairman (later restyled vice-governor) of [[Gansu]] province. He later died in [[Lanzhou]] in 1960. [[Ma Hongkui]] fled with the Kuomintang to [[Taiwan]]. He was indicted by Republic of China Control Yuan as a scapegoat. He later migrated to the United States, where he died on January 14, 1970. [[Ma Bufang]] with his son Ma Jiyuan fled by an airplane from [[Qinghai]] to [[Chongqing]], then [[Hong Kong]]. In October 1949, [[Chiang Kai-shek]] urged him to return to the Northwest to resist the PLA, but he chose to migrate to [[Saudi Arabia]] with more than 200 relatives and subordinates, in the name of [[hajj]]. He later worked as first ambassador to Saudi Arabia for Rep. of China. [[Ma Lin (warlord)|Ma Lin]]'s eldest son Ma Burong defected to the Communists after 1949 and donated 10,000 Yuan to support Chinese troops in the [[Korean War]].[http://www.360doc.com/content/11/0917/16/112480_149020067.shtml 民国少数民族将军(组图)2 - 360Doc个人图书馆] One of Ma Chengxiang's Hui officers, Ma Fuchen [[w:zh:馬輔臣|馬輔臣]], defected to the Communists.{{cite
